articles.headline: Facebook Use Polarizing? Site Begs to Differ
articles.snippet: Almost 29 percent of the news stories displayed by Facebook’s News Feed present views that conflict with the user’s own ideology, the study found.
articles.abstract: Almost 29 percent of the news stories displayed by Facebook’s News Feed present views that conflict with the user’s own ideology, the study found.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, political scientists and social theorists have fretted about the Internet’s potential to flatten and polarize democratic discourse.

articles.headline: Obama Chooses Nike Headquarters to Make His Pitch on Trade
articles.snippet: While labor activists have criticized the apparel maker, Nike says that it has learned from its mistakes and that freer trade would benefit Americans.
articles.abstract: While labor activists have criticized the apparel maker, Nike says that it has learned from its mistakes and that freer trade would benefit Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — During years of debate about the costs and benefits of trade, few businesses came to symbolize the dark side of international commerce more than Nike, the multibillion-dollar apparel giant with armies of low-paid factory workers in Asia stitching together Air Jordans.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: Uber Joins the Bidding for Here, Nokia’s Digital Mapping Service
articles.snippet: The battle to buy Here highlights the growing importance of digital mapping services as companies connect their products to the Internet.
articles.abstract: The battle to buy Here highlights the growing importance of digital mapping services as companies connect their products to the Internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: Uber is best known for allowing people to book a taxi through its smartphone application. But the fast-growing company has far broader ambitions.
articles.byline: By Mark Scott and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: How Jonathan Steinberg Made Good on a Second Chance
articles.snippet: Despite setbacks that included his father’s failures as well as his own, Jonathan Steinberg now runs one of the fastest-growing fund companies around.
articles.abstract: Despite setbacks that included his father’s failures as well as his own, Jonathan Steinberg now runs one of the fastest-growing fund companies around.
articles.lead_paragraph: From his earliest days as a 20-something chief executive, Jonathan L. Steinberg had a weekly lunch with his father, Saul, the corporate raider whose brazen tactics and lavish displays of wealth came to define Wall Street in the 1980s.

articles.headline: Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase Agree to Erase Debts From Credit Reports After Bankruptcies
articles.snippet: The two banks have agreed to update borrowers’ reports within the next three months to reflect that the debts were canceled.
articles.abstract: The two banks have agreed to update borrowers’ reports within the next three months to reflect that the debts were canceled.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two of the nation’s biggest banks will finally put to rest the zombies of consumer debt — bills that are still alive on credit reports although legally eliminated in bankruptcy — potentially providing relief to more than a million Americans.

articles.headline: Bank of America’s Relief for Mortgage Borrowers Is Questioned
articles.snippet: Under its settlement with the Justice Department, Bank of America has in some cases offered forgiveness for loans already discharged in bankruptcy.
articles.abstract: Under its settlement with the Justice Department, Bank of America has in some cases offered forgiveness for loans already discharged in bankruptcy.
articles.lead_paragraph: There was plenty of fanfare last August when Bank of America agreed to a record $16.7 billion settlement with the Justice Department over dubious mortgage practices. Prosecutors crowed about the deal, which required the bank to provide $7 billion of consumer relief — including such things as loan modifications — over the ensuing four years.

articles.headline: Guy Carawan Dies at 87; Taught a Generation to Overcome, in Song
articles.snippet: With his performance of “We Shall Overcome” at the inaugural meeting of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee in 1960, Mr. Carawan turned a little-known folk song into an anthem.
articles.abstract: With his performance of “We Shall Overcome” at the inaugural meeting of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee in 1960, Mr. Carawan turned a little-known folk song into an anthem.
articles.lead_paragraph: On an April night in 1960, Guy Carawan stood before a group of black students in Raleigh, N.C., and sang a little-known folk song. With that single stroke, he created an anthem that would echo into history, sung at the Selma-to-Montgomery marches of 1965, in apartheid-era South Africa, in international demonstrations in support of the Tiananmen Square protesters, at the dismantled Berlin Wall and beyond.

articles.headline: Monsanto, in Bid for Syngenta, Reaches for a Business It Left Behind
articles.snippet: As the pace of genetic modification slows, a company that refashioned itself from chemicals to biotechnology shows interest in diversifying back into pesticides.
articles.abstract: As the pace of genetic modification slows, a company that refashioned itself from chemicals to biotechnology shows interest in diversifying back into pesticides.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the last two decades Monsanto has cast off its century-long history as a chemical company and refashioned itself as an agricultural life sciences company, led by its genetically engineered seeds.
articles.byline: By Andrew Pollack and Chad Bray

articles.headline: U.S. Economy Added 223,000 Jobs in April; Unemployment Rate at 5.4%
articles.snippet: The gain was in line with the consensus forecast of 230,000 jobs added, and the expectation had been that the unemployment rate would tick down slightly.
articles.abstract: The gain was in line with the consensus forecast of 230,000 jobs added, and the expectation had been that the unemployment rate would tick down slightly.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American job market rebounded in April, the government said on Friday, easing fears that the economy was on the brink of another extended slowdown after a bleak winter stall. But the growth in jobs failed to translate, once again, into any significant improvement in pay.

articles.headline: Obama Scolds Democrats on Trade Pact Stance
articles.snippet: The president, battling for passage of one of the final initiatives of his presidency, said liberals opposed to the accord were “just wrong.”
articles.abstract: The president, battling for passage of one of the final initiatives of his presidency, said liberals opposed to the accord were “just wrong.”
articles.lead_paragraph: BEAVERTON, Ore. — President Obama on Friday lashed out at critics within his own party as he accused fellow Democrats of deliberately distorting the potential impact of the sweeping new trade agreement he is negotiating with Asia and standing in the way of a modern competitive economy.

articles.headline: To Cameron, the Tory Victor, Now Go the Headaches
articles.snippet: The Conservatives have such a narrow majority that Prime Minister David Cameron will have to tread carefully over thorny issues that could redefine 21st-century Britain.
articles.abstract: The Conservatives have such a narrow majority that Prime Minister David Cameron will have to tread carefully over thorny issues that could redefine 21st-century Britain.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron, having achieved a smashing and unexpected outright victory in Britain’s general election, heads into his second term facing severe challenges to his nation’s identity and place in the world: how to keep the United Kingdom in the European Union and Scotland in the United Kingdom.
